snippet: A judge’s approval would signify the end of the players’ dispute with EA Sports and the Collegiate Licensing Company but would not halt the litigation against the N.C.A.A. in the Ed O’Bannon case.
abstract: College athletes, prohibited under NCAA rules from being paid, are moving closer to being compensated for the use of their likenesses in video games; lawyers representing players in a class-action lawsuit ask a federal judge in Oakland, Calif, to approve a $40 million settlement that, the filing says, could pay the athletes as much as $951 per season in which their likenesses appeared in one of the games since 2003.
lead_paragraph: A judge’s approval would signify the end of the players’ dispute with EA Sports and the Collegiate Licensing Company but would not halt the litigation against the N.C.A.A. in the Ed O’Bannon case.

headline.main: Players Seek Approval of $40 Million Deal in Video Games Case
headline.print_headline: Players Seek Approval of $40 Million Deal in Video Games Case
